channel.title: A question about combat experience gain
channel.description: When you hit something and gain experience, is the amount controlled through a set number multiplied by the damage you deal, or the individual NPC you're attacking? I want to know for editing experience given. Also, it would be helpful if someone could tell me about experience gains from getting a log from a tree (Normal tree for the purposes of the discussion), or other non-combat instances.

item.title: A question about combat experience gain
item.dc:creator: @xx_qwertyuiop_xx xx qwertyuiop xx
item.description:
@xx_qwertyuiop_xx wrote:

[quote=“x blitz x, post:5, topic:252163”][quote author=xx qwertyuiop xx link=topic=333001.msg2596234#msg2596234 date=1230002872]

When you hit something and gain experience, is the amount controlled through a set number multiplied by the damage you deal, or the individual NPC you’re attacking?

Usually when you gain experience it is based on a value such as your level or the amount you hit on the NPC and multiplied by a set number like you said.
This usually applies to all skills.
[/quote]
I think Runescapes for attack, strength and defense is: (hit ammount) * 4.[/quote]
Yeah.
And if you’re using a controlled style of attack, it gets divided equally among all three melee skills, which is 1.33.

Read full topic
item.source: A question about combat experience gain

item.title: A question about combat experience gain
item.dc:creator: @x_blitz_x x blitz x
item.description:
@x_blitz_x wrote:

[quote=“xx qwertyuiop xx, post:2, topic:252163”][quote]
When you hit something and gain experience, is the amount controlled through a set number multiplied by the damage you deal, or the individual NPC you’re attacking?
[/quote]
Usually when you gain experience it is based on a value such as your level or the amount you hit on the NPC and multiplied by a set number like you said.
This usually applies to all skills.[/quote]
I think Runescapes for attack, strength and defense is: (hit ammount) * 4.

Read full topic

item.description:

*hitdiff
What you need?

Search it
XX*hitdiff

XX is the exp number each, range hit, or w/e

Thanks for your help.
